data.title: All icons disappeared after update
data.body: Just updated Atom to 1.10.2 (includes Nuclide, added some other packages in the same update step). And all icons have disappeared. Not a showstopper. But annoying nonetheless.

data.title: Symlinked directories on remote linux boxes - SFTP net drive
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Atom version: 1.10.2
OS Version: Windows 10 Pro, Version 1607, Build 14393.222
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
  Yes
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
  Yes 
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
  Yes, This would be a seperate fuzzy finder issue
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
  Yes
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
  Probably...
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
  Yes
### Description

Sub-issue 1) When using "File -> Open Folder..." to open a folder within a remote filesystem mounted by SFTP Net drive Atom does not see symlinked directories (which File explorer sees) within the directory in question
Sub-issue 2) When opening a symlinked directory within a remote filesystem mounted by SFTP Net drive Atom atom opens a new untitled file.
Sub-issue 3) When using "File -> Open File" to open a file under a symlinked directory within a remote filesystem mounted by SFTP Net drive, Atom reads the file and displays it, but raises "Unable to save file '<Path/to/symlinked/dir>'
EEXIST: file already exists, mkdir '<Path/to/symlinked/dir>'" When attempting to save the file after editting it.
[Description of the bug or feature]

Atom CAN open folders under symlinked directories and files under such folders normally.

In summary, this is a directory structure that you're used to:

```
FileSystem Z:
    -directory1(can be opened normally using "File -> Open Folder..."
    -simlink1(to a directory) (Is not listed under explored) (Is opened as an untitled file using "Open Folder")
        -file1 (can be opened but can't be saved)
        -directory(can be opened normally)
            -file2(can be opened and saved)
```

data.title: Should warn on unsaved files if restorePreviousWindowsOnStart = true
data.body:
Test case:
1. Enable `restorePreviousWindowsOnStart` in your configuration (see #10623)
2. Open atom
3. Edit that blank file
4. Quit

Expected outcome

> Would you like to save changes to this file?

Actual outcome

Atom quits without warning. You lose anything you were working on.

data.title: Remove shadow DOM from `atom-text-editor`
data.body:
### Background

Back in #3943, we started rendering text editor contents inside a shadow DOM boundary to prevent outer style sheets from altering the editor inner contents. Although this introduced many benefits, it carried several tradeoffs too.

In particular, we started duplicating some of the style sheets (`{context: 'atom-text-editor'}`) inside each shadow root so that package and theme authors could still be able to explicitly target the editor visual elements. An alternative solution to this problem that we suggested (before the shadow DOM spec was finalized) was to use `/deep/` and `::shadow` pseudo selectors, which unfortunately are now [being deprecated](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=489954).

Even more importantly, this architecture was getting in the way of making `atom-text-editor` a reusable component, because it made it even more coupled to Atom and its ecosystem. Other problems involved things like #4590, and a more complex user experience for package and theme authors in general. Ultimately, we started feeling like the extra complexity of the shadow DOM wasn't worth its benefits.
### Removing shadow DOM from `atom-text-editor`

This pull request aims at removing the shadow DOM in a way that prevents elements within `atom-text-editor` that we don't fully control (i.e. the grammar scopes applied as CSS classes to every line's inner `<span>`) from being mistakenly styled from the outside. Specifically, every syntactic class name will now be prepended with `syntax--`; styling a JavaScript operator, for example, should now look like the following:

``` css
.syntax--source.syntax--js .syntax--operator {
  color: green;
}
```

Given the wide scope of this change, we are trying to reduce package breakage to a minimum by [transforming deprecated selectors automatically](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/as-deprecate-shadow-dom/src/style-manager.js#L251-L306) and emitting a deprecation in [deprecation-cop](https://github.com/atom/deprecation-cop). Applying these transformations can be quite onerous and therefore we have introduced a layer of caching in 07d56b2 to ensure their performance impact stays low after the first time Atom is launched. 

Other notable changes include:
- Block decorations rendering has been rewritten from scratch (it previously worked only with the shadow DOM).
- When the editor is focused, `document.activeElement` will now return the hidden `<input>` inside `atom-text-editor`, instead of `atom-text-editor` itself. I could find only one third party package relying on this behavior, and I am going to submit a pull request shortly to use `document.activeElement.closest('atom-text-editor')` instead.
- Any Grim or style sheet deprecation will now cause specs to fail, see [`ensureNoDeprecatedFunctionCalls`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/as-deprecate-shadow-dom/spec/spec-helper.coffee#L121) and [`ensureNoDeprecatedStylesheets`](ensureNoDeprecatedStylesheets).
- Rendering flashes for decorations has been broken for a long time, but removing the shadow DOM highlighted the cause of the issue, and so they have been fixed in 1091b0e.
  
  ![flash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/19191430/b0e90580-8ca2-11e6-8272-c2d47fa4c8e5.gif)
### Conclusion

Removing the shadow DOM is an important step for the editor's future, as doing so will allow us to extract it, clean it up and optimize it. Considering the invasive nature of this change, we are planning to :ship: it after rolling the railcars next week, so that everyone can build it from master and extensively test it for an entire release cycle.

Before merging this, we will also need to merge the following core package pull requests, so that we stop using any deprecated API or selector, and make the test suite green again:
- [x] :arrow_up: autocomplete-plus (https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/779)
- [x] :arrow_up: autosave (https://github.com/atom/autosave/pull/71)
- [x] :arrow_up: atom-dark-syntax (https://github.com/atom/atom-dark-syntax/pull/31)
- [x] :arrow_up: atom-dark-ui (https://github.com/atom/atom-dark-ui/pull/64)
- [x] :arrow_up: atom-light-syntax (https://github.com/atom/atom-light-syntax/pull/9)

data.title: Avoid forcing computation of all screen lines when opening a file
data.body:
When opening a large file, the majority of time before the file appears on screen is spent building the DisplayLayer's index of screen coordinates to buffer coordinates. As of https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/175, the DisplayLayer can now compute this information lazily. This PR adjusts our usage of the display layer so that when possible, we avoid indexing the entire buffer.
### Benchmarks
#### Before (v1.12-beta0)

On my machine, opening a 10MB file used to take over 5 seconds:

![opening-before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/19403539/d3dbf136-921c-11e6-8c06-627afd337458.png)

Once the file was on screen, there was a long period in which the application was unresponsive because of work being done in the `autocomplete-plus` package. This was partially addressed in https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/782, which disables symbol indexing for large files. The following graph only goes up to 6MB because for files larger than that, the editor crashed 😬 .

![before-event-loop](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/19403611/322746d2-921d-11e6-80a8-be1cd33b41df.png)
#### After

Opening a file:

Now, when opening a 10MB file, it appears on screen in two seconds second:

![after-opening](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/19404390/77c8dcf0-9222-11e6-8c6c-fdd314e02e31.png)

The application remains responsive afterwards:

![after-event-loop](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/19404382/6800b14e-9222-11e6-8771-ec2bbffd90d4.png)

data.title: Add methods for checking if initial packages have been loaded/activated
data.body:
This will allow packages to observe the state without having to worry
about subscribing to the events after they've already fired.

Originally suggested in #10839

data.title: Using an apostrophe within a <script> tag while writing an HTML pattern breaks syntax highlighting
data.body:
When using backbone/underscore, I oftentimes need to write HTML within a _script_ tag that will then be rendered as a pattern that underscore can use as a template to execute JS against.

Unfortunately, if my string contains an apostrophe, Atom thinks I'm trying to define a string and will trigger an open-ended syntax highlight event.

Here is a screenshot: http://dl.dpeck.net/1j3q6

Any tips to work around this are greatly appreciates.

data.title: Incorrect selection highlight after pane resize
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

After selecting a region of code and resizing the pane, the highlight will _visually_ be in the incorrect position, but it still is actually where the original highlight was.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. The easiest way to reproduce this is by creating a new pane, such as through Markdown Preview, though simply splitting the current pane works as well.
2. Open a `.md` file.
3. Highlight some text
4. `markdown-preview:toggle`
5. The text should still be highlighted at this point
6. `markdown-preview:toggle`
7. ?!
8. You can verify that the highlight is still in the correct place through a variety of ways: using the arrow keys to move the cursor, cutting the highlighted text, etc.

![incorrect-selection-on-pane-resize](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2766036/19156576/5ffa4bb8-8bb0-11e6-9dbc-1b7ab4ea60c6.gif)

**Expected behavior:** The highlight to visually stay in the correct place.

**Actual behavior:** The highlight moves! :ghost:
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.


data.title: Accessibility: No Option To Change Text Size
data.body:
There is an option to change editor text size but not for the rest of the UI.
Even after editing a custom stylesheet, many elements are still too small (for me) to read. It is unclear how to universally increase the size.
All sizes need to be relative to a global modifier.

data.title: Disabling atomic soft tabs does not work on a whitespace-only line
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [Y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [Y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [Y] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [Y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

The "Atomic Soft Tabs" setting cannot be disabled - or more clearly, the checkbox that is on by default can be unselected, but the effect of cursor skipping over soft tabs does not change.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Ensure that "soft tabs" and "show invisibles" settings are on, and Tab Type is set to auto/soft.
2. Create a new file, and press the tab key to indent.
3. Observe that 4 "dots" appear to represent the tab as four spaces, i.e. a soft tab.
4. move the cursor using the keyboard, and observe if the cursor skips over the spaces as a whole, or allows the cursor to move over each space one by one. Also try and select a middle space using the mouse cursor.

**Expected behavior:** with the 'Atomic Soft Tabs' setting off, I would expect the cursor to be able to select spaces within a soft tab.

**Actual behavior:** the cursor skips over all the spaces, i.e. Atomic Soft Tab behaviour.
### Versions

RHEL7.2

$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.5
git 1.8.3.1

data.title: Exclude VCS Ignored Paths excludes the VCS-controlled files
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When the file matches the VCS ignore conditions but is still present in the repository (due to being forcefully added), it is still excluded from the view.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a git repository, add it to Atom project.
2. In Atom, enable the Exclude VCS Ignored Paths.
3. Create a .gitignore file, add some condition.
4. Create a file matching the condition from previous step. Using `git add -f`, add it to the repository.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The file is displayed in Atom.

The rationale is: all VCS-controlled files are definitely a part of the project; the .gitignore contains the rules what files should not bother me suggesting to add it to the commit; but if I've added it already, it is the part of the project since that moment. Since the moment I've added it via `git add -f`, Git now tracks the changes in that file; whenever the file is changed, its changes are now reflected in the `git status`; that is, from the Git viewpoint, using `git add -f` overrides the .gitignore rule. Atom should behave accordingly to Git.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The file is not displayed in Atom.
### Versions

macOS 10.12

~:$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

~:$ apm --version 
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.8.4
